Finding aid for
Robert C. Stempel papers, 1965-2007
titlepage.author:
Finding aid created by
Michigan Historical Collections staff, 2012

did.abstract: Designer and automotive engineer with the General Motors Corporation; he later assumed increasing responsibilities within the company as president and chief operating officer and then chairman and chief executive officer. After leaving GM, he became chairman of Energy Conversion Devices (ECD). The Stempel collection documents his work with GMC and ECD and includes minutes of meetings, company memoranda and correspondence, speeches and other various presentations, publications, and photographs and other visual materials. Portions of the collection relate to other business and public service affiliations.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by the family of Robert C. Stempel (donor no. 10732) and came to the library in February 2012.

accruals.p: No further additions to the records are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research except for files less than twenty years old which are closed to research. These files relate to Stempel's involvement with Energy Conversion Devices and are found in boxes 20-37.

userestrict.p: The family of Robert Stempel transferred their copyright to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Robert C. Stempel papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Robert Carl Stempel was born July 15, 1933, in Trenton, N.J. He received a bachelor of science degree in mechanical engineering from Worcester Polytechnic Institute in Massachusetts in 1955. He later earned a master's degree in business administration from Michigan State University in 1970.

In 1958, after serving two years in the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, Stempel joined GM's Oldsmobile Division as a senior detailer in the chassis design department. He later served as senior designer (1962); transmission design engineer (1964); motor engineer (1969); and assistant chief engineer (1972). Stempel was a member of the team that developed the 1966 Toronado, the first modern American front-wheel-drive car. According to a GM biography, Stempel designed the Toronado's front suspension and its engine and transmission mounting system. He also participated in the development of the first catalytic converter.

In 1973 Stempel was appointed special assistant to the president of General Motors. He joined the engineering department of the Chevrolet Division as chief engineer-engines and components in 1974 and was named Chevrolet's director of engineering in 1975.

On November 6, 1978, Mr. Stempel was appointed general manager of the Pontiac Motor Division and elected a vice president of General Motors. In September 1980, he was appointed managing director of Adam Opel AG (the German subsidiary of GM) in the Federal Republic of Germany, with responsibility for European-sourced passenger-car operations. In 1982, he returned to Detroit as General Manager of Chevrolet.

In January 1984, he was promoted to the dual responsibility of Vice President and Group Executive in Charge of the Buick-Oldsmobile-Cadillac group. He was elected to the board of directors (February, 1986). He became president and chief operating officer of General Motors Corporation on September 1, 1987. In August 1990, he became chairman and chief executive officer. He resigned in 1992.

In 1993, Stempel joined Stanford Ovshinsky founder of Energy Conversion Devices (ECD) as an adviser. Stempel was named chairman in 1995. In 1999, ECD partnered with Intel in a joint-venture called Ovonyx which developed nonsilicon-based memory for electronic devices. Subsequently ECD formed joint ventures with Texaco Energy Systems Inc., GE Plastics and Belgium-based N.V. Bekaert S.A.
Stempel retired from ECD in 2007; he died May 7, 2011 in West Palm Beach Florida.

scopecontent.p: The Robert C. Stempel collection has been arranged into the following series: General Motors Corporation; Energy Conversion Devices; Speeches / Conferences / Presentations; Organizational Affiliations, Responsibilities, and Interests; Background / Personal information; Visual Materials, and Sound Cassettes.

Electric automobiles.
Energy conversion.

scopecontent.p: The largest series in the collection relates to Stempel's career with General Motors. This series has been further divided by phases or career moves made by Stempel. These include Various Early Responsibilities (1965-1980); President and Chief Operating Officer (1987-1990); Chairman / Chief Executive Officer (1990-1992); and Later Responsibilities (1992-1999). In addition, there are three subseries, one consisting of the depositions made by Stempel as part of litigation involving General Motors. The other two subseries are a collection of General Motors publications and files of RCS schedules and itineraries. Of interest are files relating to the development of the Toronado and to the company's response to issues of automotive emissions in the 1970s.

scopecontent.p: The Energy Conversion Devices details the founding and development of this company through the records of the annual meeting and the board of directors. A significant portion of the files relate to presentation made by Stempel on behalf of the company to various banking and asset management firms. Some of the files relate to Stempel's enthusiasm for electric vehicles. Within this series are compact discs (CD-R) of the power-point presentations made by RCS.

accessrestrict.p: [RESTRICTED until 20 years from the creation of the record]

scopecontent.p: The Speeches / Conferences / Presentations series mainly covers the period when Stempel was with General Motors.

The Organizational Affiliations, Responsibilities, and Interests series documents Stempel's leadership within the National Commission Against Drunk Driving and his participation as a member of Presidential Business Delegation to Asia and the Pacific, December 30, 1991-January 10, 1992.

scopecontent.p: The Background / Personal information series is highlighted by the transcript of an oral history interview RCS gave relating to his career with General Motors. There are also hundreds of letters he received following various GM promotions and when he resigned as chairman and chief executive officer.

scopecontent.p: The Visual Materials includes materials from throughout RCS's career. It includes photographs and slides from through his life. There are other visual materials (films and videotapes) in other series as indicated in this finding aid.

scopecontent.p: The Audio Cassettes are recordings of Stempel's appearances on various radio programs as well as other public presentations.
